title: alternative to copperplate
content:
i'm looking for a font that is an alternative to copperplate. i have a client for whom i'm designing a logo, and he feels that all the fonts i've shown thus far are too 'common.' (these included: requiem, didot, castellar, futura, among others.) he has asked for a 'clean, crisp, unique, formidable, stately' font. he particularly likes the font used for the french laundry logo ( [http://www.frenchlaundry.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.frenchlaundry.com/ "http://www.frenchlaundry.com/") click on 'menu + stories' then click 'menu'. unfortunately, i can't find it anywhere that's clear to view other than a downloadable menu.) i believe it's copperplate that has been modified.  
i have a feeling this is one of those cases where he needs to see many options and will (hopefully) fall in love eventually. i don't think a sans serif is appropriate. thanks for any direction to lesser known, well designed fonts.
author: emilydesigns

comments.content: The French Laundy logo is indeed a modified Copperplate. Wiescher has a [Copperplate with similar flourishes](http://web.archive.org/) but it's not very well drawn. Your client might be interested in [Estilo](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/dstype/estilo_regular/) and [Estilo Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/dstype/estilo_script/) or the spur seriffed [Friz Quadrata](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/itc/itc_friz_quadrata_by_adobe_std_bold/) and [ITC Elan](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/itc_elan_std_virtual/). Finally, [Classica](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/presence_typo/classica_prestige/) offers a large set of inscriptional ligatures that make quench his thirst for "stately".

You could also try Engravers Gothic.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-gothic/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-gothic/")

Sorry I didn't see that part about sans serif,

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-oldstyle-205/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-oldstyle-205/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/engravers-oldstyle-205/")
You might consider [Beaufort Medium Extended](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.shinntype.com/beaufort.html), in capitals.

Trajan has a ’clean, crisp, formidable, stately’ to it. However I wouldn't say it is too original.

[http://www.linotype.com/1547/trajan-family.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.linotype.com/1547/trajan-family.html "http://www.linotype.com/1547/trajan-family.html")

If your client is really insisting on Copperplate, [Biondi](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.typodermic.com/32.html) might be a palatable alternative.

Too bad my [Palormak](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/typophile.com/node/28416) isn't quite ready yet.
I personally stick with Helvetica, Bodoni, Times Roman, Century, Futura. They are all very beautiful.

Take a look at [Alusine](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.smeltery.net/fonts/alusine) and [GEronto - Bis](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.smeltery.net/fonts/geronto-bis), there are others from this French foundry that might fit the bill. You may also like [Anisette](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Anisette).
You can also find a lot of inspiration in the FontShop newsletters [HERE](http://web.archive.org/web/20140314140105/http:/www.fontshop.com/features/newsletters/).

thanks for some great suggestions. i especially love the french foundry fonts, as well as beaufort medium, biondi and palormak (not ready.) the fontshop newsletters are great inspiration - thank you! given that my client will 'know it when he sees it' i think i'll present him with screen shots of many of these options.

Wow, GEronto - Bis is gorgeous!
